Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program supports Dr. Charles E. Doubleday of Columbia University for the devleopment of non-statistical computational methods to better understand organic reaction mechanisms. This research will develop methods to compute the detailed sequence of atomic motions as starting materials are transformed into products (classical trajectories), using a combination of quantum mechanics and classical mechanics. Dr. Doubleday will examine reactions that are important in organic chemistry, and whose mechanisms of operation have remained elusive. These include unimolecular isomerizations and some bimolecular cycloadditions. A third type is enediyne cyclizations that occur in a powerful class of naturally occuring antibiotics. Dr. Doubleday will study quantum mechanical tunneling in these reactions, in addition to computing classical trajectories. In all projects, the goal is to understand the way in which energy flows from reactants to products. The deeper understanding gained will allow more precise control in designing molecules for specific applications.
Â 
An important component of this project is the training of undergraduate students in scientific research. Since research is collaborative and students learn from each other, the work fosters group skills as well as individual achievement. In collaborations with colleagues at other institutions, Dr. Doubleday helps train graduate students in the use of trajectory methods. The principal investigator's classical trajectory program is available and is currently being used at other academic institutions. Benefits to society at large will emerge from a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of chemical reactions. In the enediyne project, the focus is on the active center of a class of powerful antibiotics, with the goal of understanding and control. As the principles uncovered by this research become incorporated into applied areas, potential benefits could include greater understanding and control over chemical processes important in atmospheric and life processes, and in human health generally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal is to understand the fundamental basis for selectivity in chemical reactions. Reactions that produce two or more products must pass through a branch point, at which the atoms choose which product to form. To understand the physical basis for such choices, we compute the detailed sequence of atomic motions during the reaction, using the method of quasiclassical trajectories, or QCTs. Insights provided by QCTs can lead to experimental strategies for favoring one product over another. QCTs were carried out for a number of gas-phase cycloadditions, or ring-forming reactions. We have recently adapted the QCT method for liquid phase reactions with explicit solvation. Another project examines the acceleration of reactions due to the wave nature of hydrogen and carbon atoms, an effect called quantum mechanical tunneling. It has been applied to an important reaction in the prebiotic era (the formose reaction) and to a reaction used in a class of antibiotics (Bergman cyclization).

An important component of this project is the training of undergraduate students in scientific research. In this grant period, six Columbia students were trained in the use of computational methods for modeling chemical reactions. Through collaborations with colleagues at UCLA, Baruch College CUNY, and Brigham Young University, students in other departments were trained as well. Our trajectory code is freely available and is in use at other academic institutions. Benefits to society at large will emerge from a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of chemical reactions sought in our research. As the principles uncovered by this work become incorporated into applied areas, potential benefits could include greater understanding and control over the chemistry of materials and life processes.

Specific outcomes are described for quasiclassical trajectories and quantum mechanical tunneling for the period 08/01/2014 - 07/31/2015.

Trajectory dynamics projects.

  • (FIGURE 1)  In quasiclassical trajectory calculations of Bergman cyclization of (Z)-3-hexen-1,5-diyne, we found that the newly formed CC bond retains its energy, and 28% of nascent p-benzyne recrosses to the enediyne on an ultrashort vibrational time scale. The competing process of intramolecular vibrational redistribution (IVR) in p-benzyne is too slow to prevent this. Deuteration increases the rate of IVR, which decreases the fraction of recrossing and increases the yield of statistical (trapable) p-benzyne product, resulting in substantial H/D kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) for cyclization. In this classical simulation, the effect on KIEs of nonphysical flow of zero point vibrational energy (ZPE) out of CH and CD stretching modes into the reaction coordinate was estimated by varying the ZPE. We found that ZPE leakage is much greater from CD stretching modes than CH modes, and the KIEs are insensitive to ZPE leakage. An experimental confirmation of the predicted KIEs would imply that IVR, an important process in all chemical reactions, is amenable to study by conventional KIEs.
  • (FIGURE 2)  In collaboration with the Houk group at UCLA, we studied an important bioorthogonal reaction, cycloadditions of tetrazines with cyclopropenes and other strained alkenes. These reactions give Diels-Alder adducts that spontaneously lose N2 to form a stable product. The lifetime distributions of the initial Diels-Alder adducts are oscillatory as a result of gating by a specific vibrational mode. In the case of cyclopropene, there is a strong energetic preference for loss of the anti-N2 from the initial adduct, but trajectories reveal a 1000000-fold dynamic preference for loss of syn-N2.
